title: Ticket #7080: Auto-approve token rules
description:
Now that we have the ability to request tokens in #7006, we should allow the sysadmin to install auto-approval rules:

  1. These rules should be time-limited (i.e., admin needs to specify that they are only valid for 1 hour).
    • To allow for pools coming up quickly, requests predating the rule's installation (say, by 30 seconds) should be approved once the rule is installed.
  2. The admin should be able to specify a netblock (e.g., 192.168.0.0/24) the rule is valid for.
  3. The rule should only allow a very narrow set of fixed authorizations and identities. That is, this should only be allowed for token requests with the identity condor and requesting the authorization for ADVERTISE_SCHEDD or ADVERTISE_STARTD.
remarks:
2019-May-30 14:37:19 by tlmiller:

BrianB and I had a discussion and we agree that:

  • The CLI should have a default lifetime, but not a default netmask, unless (bonus feature) PRIVATE_NETWORK_NAME is set, in which case the default is the private network . Otherwise, we just have to ask (and not do anything).

  • The CLI should tell the user what we're doing (e.g., confirm lifetime with time units and netmask).

  • Instead of trying to guess a good time-out for historical auto-approval, the CLI should list all of the requests from that time period (just like the list tokens command) and say "to approve all these requests, run the following command." It should also mention, if there are any requests older than that, how to get a list of them (e..g, condor_list_tokens <num... num>).

  • We should always log autoapprovals, but the first autoapproval for each rule should also log the rule in question (like security rejections).

  • condor_reconfig should flush (delete) the autoapproval rules (and the collector should log that they're gone). This may be a little surprising, but we can argue that since the rules aren't in the config files, they shouldn't be in the configuration after a reconfig.

  • Likewise, condor_config should flush (delete) pending requests.

2019-Jun-10 08:59:04 by bbockelm:
The PR https://github.com/htcondor/htcondor/pull/50 should have all the above addressed except for the PRIVATE_NETWORK_NAME pieces; that's a good idea, but isn't really how that particular knob works.

2019-Jun-21 08:26:43 by bbockelm:
Merged master back into the branch and updated GitHub. ctest run looks good on RHEL7.

Ready for review.

2019-Jun-28 17:24:35 by tlmiller:
Code Review

  1. I hoisted two of the checks out the per-rule loop in TokenRequest::ShouldAutoApprove(), because they didn't depend on the rule. Let me know if you had meant to be inefficient there for the sake of the logging.
  2. I moved the unimplemented features from the commentary to #7137.
  3. This is bad and wrong: 
    $ condor_token_request_auto_approve -netblock 192.168.0.0/36 -lifetime 3700
Successfully installed auto-approval rule for netblock 192.168.0.0/36 with lifetime of 1.03 hours
    So is this: 
    condor_token_request_auto_approve -netblock 192::168.0.0/36 -lifetime -3700
Successfully installed auto-approval rule for netblock 192::168.0.0/36 with lifetime of -1.03 hours
Remote daemon reports no un-approved requests pending.
    I don't know that we need to have the CLI do any particular filtering, but it seems like the server should.
